1.title: Golf
1.author: by Carl Grubert.
1.series: May 3, 1952) "Between Them They Hold the Curse Record and the Course Record!"*

2.title: Golf
2.author: by Harry Haenigsen.
2.series: May 3, 1952) "I'm Utterly Way Off My Game Today"*
notes: Summary: Penny's on the green, but she usually lands in the sand trap.

3.title: Golf
3.author: by Berndt.
3.series: June 10, 1952) "I'll Hit 'em and You Throw 'em Back, Smitty"*
notes: Summary: The boss is practicing golf in the office, and the ball bounces off the wall.

4.title: Golf
4.author: by Berndt.
4.series: June 14, 1952) "I'll Give Him a Rubber Ball to Practice With"*
notes: Summary: The boss is practicing golf in the office, and he might break something.

5.title: Golf
5.author: [No author]
notes: Data from Lou Mougin via Grand Comic-Book Database.

6.title: Golf
6.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Mr. Magoo thinks he finds his golf ball in a hen's nest.

8.title: Golf
8.author: [No author]
8.series: Jan. 17, 1953) "I Finally Shot Par on the Tenlakes Golf Course"*
notes: Summary: Because the lakes are frozen, Donald has been golfing in ice skates.

9.title: Golf
9.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: An angry golf course manager is fooled by Donald's wearing his latest divot on his head.

10.title: Golf
10.author: by V
notes: Summary: Alley's friends convince themselves that they should take him to see a doctor. As they say he's "way below par," Alley is shown swinging his axe at a rock, golf-style.

11.title: Golf
11.author: Hanan.
notes: Summary: Dr. Zigsby is just leaving for golf when Louie arrives, and after a quick listen with the stethoscope takes Louie golfing.

12.title: Golf
12.author: Hanan.
notes: Summary: Louie daydreams about golf, and after the boss yells at him his daydream includes the boss as his caddy.
Wordless strip.

13.title: Golf
13.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Dad wants to go golfing, but Mom makes him mow the lawn.

14.title: Golf
14.author: [No author]
14.series: May 6, 1954) "Practicing the Approach on Baxter's Carrots"
notes: Summary: Amos talks about his ancestor, Angus McQuarrie Hoople, who taught King James the game of golf in Scotland ; the neighbor wants him to stop tramping through his garden retrieving the ball.

15.title: Golf
15.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major is in trouble for picking up somebody else's golf ball.

16.title: Golf
16.author: [No author]
16.series: May 13, 1954) "No More Than Three Balls, That Is"
notes: Summary: The Major reports on his preparations for the golf tournament; he played a difficult dogleg hole with no more than three.

17.title: Golf
17.author: by Charles M
17.series: May 16, 1954) "Lucille Van Pelt on the First Tee, Please"
notes: Summary: Lucy has entered a golf tournament, and worries about playing against Sam Snead, Ben Hogan, and Ike. Charlie Brown reminds her that it's a women's tournament.

This Sunday strip is reproduced as part of a letter to the editor, as evidence that grownups (here only from the shoulders down) sometimes appeared in Peanuts. p. 14 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).

18.title: Golf
18.author: by Charles M
18.series: May 23, 1954) "There's Nothing That Can Stop You Now, Lucy!"*
notes: Summary: Lucy starts her round at the women's state amateur tournament with an eagle and a birdie.

This Sunday strip is reproduced as part of a letter to the editor, as evidence that grownups (here only from the shoulders down) sometimes appeared in Peanuts. p. 14 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).

19.title: Golf
19.author: by Charles M
19.series: May 30, 1954) "I'm Supposed to be Home Taking a Nap!"*
notes: Summary: Lucy is one hole from winning the tournament, when she suddenly leaves the golf course.

This Sunday strip is reproduced as part of a letter to the editor, as evidence that grownups (here in full figure, but in the far distance or with blank faces) sometimes appeared in Peanuts. p. 14 in Hogan's Alley, no. 9 (=v. 3, no. 1) (Summer 2001).

20.title: Golf
20.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
20.appears_in: reproduced on p. 84-85 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Swindlers Duke and Five-Spot approach Bathless Groggins with flattery and a set of golf clubs.

21.title: Golf
21.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
21.series: Aug. 22, 1954) "Two G's Right On His Ugly Nose"*
21.appears_in: reproduced on p. 86-87 in Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Duke and Five-Shot check to be sure Bathless has the golf clubs with magnets in them, then place their bet.

22.title: Golf
22.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
22.series: Aug. 29, 1954) "The Greatest Thing t'Come Along in Golf Since Bobby Jones"*
22.appears_in: reproduced on p. 88-89 in Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).

23.title: Golf
23.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
23.series: Sept. 5, 1954) "The Sensation of the Golfing World!"*
23.appears_in: reproduced on p. 90-91 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Bathless Groggins' score for the first nine holes is (gasp) ten!

24.title: Golf
24.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
24.series: Sept. 12, 1954) "The Publicity is Worth Thousands to My Company!"*
24.appears_in: reproduced on p. 92-93 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Hummock, Mashie and McStymie, makers of golf equipment, convince Groggins to finish the tournament using their clubs.

25.title: Golf
25.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
25.series: Sept. 19, 1954) "The Skull of J. Pierpont Groggins"*
25.appears_in: reproduced on p. 94-95 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Without his magnetic golf clubs, Bathless has trouble hitting the ball and ends up hitting himself in the head.

26.title: Golf
26.author: by Raeburn Van Buren
26.series: Sept. 27, 1954) "Off Yer Knees and Start Countin' Off the Long Green!"*
26.appears_in: reproduced on p. 96-97 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Hummock, Mashie and McStymie offer $20,000 to Groggins if he'll stop using their golf equipment.

28.heading: Golf (1955).
28.title: You've Got Me in a Hole : a Collection of the Best Golfing Cartoons by the Foremost Comic Artists
28.author: edited by Lawrence Lariar.
notes: 1 v. : ill. ; 29 cm.

29.title: Golf
29.author: Clark.
29.series: June 10, 1955) "We Stayed Home All Those Years While He Studied Nights. Now He's an Executive and Trying to Break 80 at Golf"
notes: Situation: Two women talking over their backyard fences; a push mower leans against a house in an unmowed lawn.

30.title: Golf
30.author: Carl Ed
30.series: June 29, 1955) "She's the Pro's Daughter Out for early Morning Practice!"*
30.appears_in: reproduced on p. 98 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Harold wants to caddy for her.

31.title: Golf
31.author: Carl Ed
31.series: July 7, 1955) "I Hope You Watched My Ball, Caddy"*
31.appears_in: reproduced on p. 99 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Harold is too distracted by Toddy to do a good job of caddying.

32.title: Golf
32.author: [No author]
notes: Golf story.

33.title: Golf
33.author: by Zeke Zekley
33.appears_in: reproduced on p. 108 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: She sees his golf bag ready to go, and replaces the clubs with housecleaning equipment.

34.title: Golf
34.author: by Lank Leonard
34.series: May 5, 1956) "Sometimes I Think Golf is Too Strenuous for a Man of Phil's Age, Mickey!"*
34.appears_in: reproduced on p. 82-83 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).

35.title: Golf
35.author: by Jimmy Hatlo
35.series: June 9, 1956) "A Little Game of Pasture Pool"*
35.appears_in: reproduced on p. 105 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Doc Gumboyle, the dentist, is calm in his office, but a nervous wreck on the golf course.

36.title: Golf
36.author: Haenigsen
36.appears_in: reproduced on p. 118 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Penny has made a floral design on her father's golf bag.

37.title: Golf
37.author: [No author]
37.series: 1957) "Do You Mind If I Play Through?"*
notes: Summary: Pop's giving Lulu golf pointers indoors, and Lulu's mom needs to vacuum.

38.title: Golf
38.author: Mel Keefer, Jordan Lansky
38.series: Jan. 1957) "Please, Stuff, You'd Be Doing Me a Favor by Staying"*
38.appears_in: reproduced on p. 117 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Stuffy takes the blame for the cracked club, and offers to resign as caddy.

39.title: Golf
39.author: by Hank Ketcham
39.series: May 13, 1959) "So He Said a Bad Word and Kicked It!"*
39.appears_in: reproduced on p. 111 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Dennis has been golfing with dad.

40.title: Golf
40.author: [No author]
40.series: June 11, 1959) "That Was The Day I First Broke A Hundred!"*
notes: Summary: Daisy feels neglected by golf-playing Donald, and bets he can't remember the day they met.

41.title: Golf
41.author: by Jimmy Hatlo
41.series: June 21, 1959) "You Can Get Away from Bigdome, But You Can't Get Away With Much!"*
41.appears_in: reproduced on p. 104 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Tremblechin is playing at St. Andrews, and his boss in America will give him $500 if he beats the boss's score. And the boss has arranged a lie-detector test.

42.title: Golf
42.author: by Jo Fisher
42.series: 1960) "You're Getting Much Better Distance With Those New Balls, Hysteria"*
42.appears_in: reproduced on p. 138 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).

43.title: Golf
43.author: by Bil Keane
43.appears_in: reproduced on p. 111 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Dad's sleeping with his mouth open in the back yard, and the kids are preparing to use the cavity for golfing.

44.title: Golf
44.author: by Carl Anderson
44.appears_in: reproduced on p. 110 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Henry uses a bearskin rug for indoor golf.

45.title: Golf
45.author: by George Clarke
45.series: June 6, 1960?) "Did Shakespeare Waste His Time on the Golf Course? I'll Bet He Was at His Typewriter All Day Long!"
45.appears_in: reproduced on p. 114 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Setting: The husband is leaving with his golf clubs.

46.title: Golf
46.author: Stan Lee
46.appears_in: 2 p. in My Girl Pearl, no. 9 (Dec. 1960)
notes: Begins: Shirl! Yoo hoo! I've been looking for you! I. Lee, Stan. k. Goofy golf. k. Golf. Call no.: PN6728.2.M3M86no.9

47.title: Golf
47.author: Mort Walker.
notes: Summary: Sarge always hits the golf ball over 300 yards, which is a problem when he putts.

48.title: Golf
48.author: by Chester Gould
48.appears_in: reproduced on p. 103 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Mr. Pardee has accidentally killed a woman with a golf shot.

49.title: Golf
49.author: by Chester Gould
49.appears_in: reproduced on p. 103 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).

50.heading: Golf (1962).
50.title: "Fore!" : Golf Cartoons from the Wall Street Journal
50.author: selected by Charles Preston.

51.title: Golf
51.author: by Ron Fox
51.series: May 1, 1962) "We'll Be a Close-Knit Family. We'll Do Everything Together"
51.appears_in: reproduced on p. 108 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The second panel has the whole family on the golf course, including three screaming children.

52.title: Golf
52.author: by Saunders & Overgard
52.appears_in: reproduced on p. 102 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary Mr. Lopar has a golf cart equipped with a bar.

53.title: Golf
53.author: by Saunders & Overgard
53.series: June 9, 1962) "I Can't Waste the Afternoon Hunting Lost Balls!"*
53.appears_in: reproduced on p. 102 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: In the woods at the golf course, Lopar's caddie/bartender Morrie pulls out a gun and points it at Steve.

54.title: Golf
54.author: Justin McCarthy and Len Reno
54.appears_in: reproduced on p. 123 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Brother Juniper is practicing golf using his shepherd's crook as a driver.

55.title: Golf
55.author: [No author]
notes: A silent strip, in which Pierre solves a problem on the golf course.
Back cover.

56.title: Golf
56.author: Mort Walker, Dik Browne
56.series: Mar. 31, 1963) "You Should Fight Your Compulsion that you Have to Play Golf Every Sunday No Matter What!"*
56.appears_in: reproduced on p. 322 of The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics (Washington : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Hi leaves to play golf in the rain and mud.

57.title: Golf
57.author: Ferd Johnson
57.appears_in: reproduced on p. 125 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Alone on the course, Winston Plushbottom nudges his ball off the edge of the 18th hole when his 100th stroke is a fraction short; then he can't bring himself to lie to other golfers.

58.title: Golf
58.author: Mel Keefer, J
58.series: Nov. 30, 1964) "Every Pro on the Circuit is Here"*
58.appears_in: Lansky. p. 85 in The National Cartoonists Society Album 1965, ed. by Mort Walker (New York : NCS, 1965).

59.title: Golf
59.author: by Phillips
59.appears_in: panel reproduced on p. 106 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: On the golf course, Mr. Mum sees a tiny ladder and shovel sticking out of the eighth hole.

60.title: Golf
60.author: by Mort Walker
60.series: May 6, 1965) "It Falls on My Shoulders to Un-Botch Them"*
60.appears_in: reproduced on p. 107 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Maneuvers are in such a bad state the General Halftrack uses a special corrective method: He starts a round of golf.

61.title: Golf
61.author: [No author]
61.series: May 24, 1965) "Never Ridicule Elderly People. You'll Be There Some Day!"*
notes: (Born Forty Years Too Soon)
Summary: Boys with shinny sticks poke fun at a passing couple of golfers. He is carrying two golf bags, and she has none.

62.title: Golf
62.author: by Cordray
62.appears_in: reproduced on p. 114 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: A golfer complains that a shot almost hit his wife.

63.title: Golf
63.author: by Stan Lynde
63.appears_in: reproduced on p. 112 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Moonglow remarks about her father's choice of opening days for the new golf course.

64.title: Golf
64.author: by Stan Lynde
64.series: Aug. 17, 1965) "Looks Like Heap Plenty Painful Game!"*
64.appears_in: reproduced on p. 113 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The chief drives a golf ball off a tree into his own face.

65.title: Golf
65.author: by Stan Lynde
65.appears_in: reproduced on p. 113 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The golf ball has knocked out the chief's gold tooth.

66.title: Golf
66.author: Neg Cochran.
66.series: Oct. 2, 1965) "I Play This Game for Exercise!"*
notes: (Grampaw)
Summary: Grampaw doesn't want to ride in the golf cart and get a bay window.

67.title: Golf
67.author: by Johnny Hart
67.appears_in: reprinted on p. 30-32 of The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 1 (Summer 1967).
notes: Summary: B.C. is playing golf, and snaps a club in half each time something goes wrong. Score for the first hole: 29 clubs.

68.title: Golf
68.author: Dik Browne
68.appears_in: reprinted on p. 152 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Thirsty explains his confidence at golf: the handle of his club is a flask of liquor.

69.title: Golf
69.author: Henry Formhals.
69.series: Dec. 23, 1966) "It's Stuck to the Golf Club!"*
notes: Summary: They may have invented a golf ball that can't be lost.

70.title: Golf
70.author: Walt Wetterberg.
notes: Summary: The cat gives the ball a swat, and it goes off the wall into the tumbler.

71.title: Golf
71.author: Dick Cavalli.
notes: Summary: A golfer is in an intersection, waiting for the traffic cop to give him permission to hit his ball.

72.title: Golf
72.author: Dick Cavalli.
72.series: Mar. 13, 1967) "I Held It Back As Long As I Could"*
notes: Summary: He's been dying to try out his new driver, and now there's a hole in the window. It's been a long winter.

73.title: Golf
73.author: Art Sansom.
notes: Summary: Thornapple is quarantined, watching Veeblefester go by with his golf clubs

74.title: Golf
74.author: by Alexander Graham
74.series: Apr. 27, 1967) "I'll Bet He's Seething Inside Though"*
74.appears_in: reproduced on p. 115 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Fred's mistress has beaten his master at golf, and he takes it 'like a man.'

75.title: Golf
75.author: by Galbraith ; Gill Fox.
75.series: May 6, 1967) "The Game Does Have a Certain Escape Value. Only This Morning I Asked Myself: Would You Rather Play Golf or Put Up Screens?"

76.title: Golf
76.author: by Galbraith ; Gill Fox.
76.series: May 15, 1967) "You and Your 10% Chance of Precipitation"
notes: Summary: A dripping golfer brings the weather prediction to the attention of the newspaper editor.

77.title: Golf
77.author: by Galbraith ; Gill Fox.
77.series: May 29, 1967) "If I Didn't Know Better, I'd Swear I Heard Someone Sob!"
notes: Summary: Below them and out of sight is a forlorn golfer in a sand trap.

78.title: Golf
78.author: Art Sansom.
78.series: June 9, 1967) "By George, Thornapple, I'm Finally Getting the Hang of It!"
notes: Summary: On the green, Veeblefester is playing with a paddleball while Brutus's putt bounces back up out of the hole.

79.title: Golf
79.author: Dick Cavalli.
79.series: June 12, 1967) "At Breakfast this Morning He Asked Me to Pass the Bread and Putter"*
notes: Summary: Sandy Trapp, the professional golfer, is staying over.

80.title: Golf
80.author: Dick Cavalli.
notes: Summary: Sandy Trapp says what his favorite food is.

81.title: Golf
81.author: by Galbraith ; Gill Fox.
81.series: June 23, 1967) "Nice Guys and Those Playing Golf with the Boss Finish Last!"

82.title: Golf
82.author: [No author]
82.series: July 5, 1967) "Try Standing Farther Away from the Ball"*
notes: Summary: A golfer knocks his own shoe off with his swing.

83.title: Golf
83.author: Art Sansom.
notes: Summary: Brutus is playing golf with Veeblefester (his boss), who isn't winning.

84.title: Golf
84.author: Gill Fox.
84.series: Aug. 15, 1967) "If the Golf Course has Non-Allergy Grass, How Come We Can't Have It?"
notes: Setting: She's mowing the lawn, and he's loading his golf clubs in the trunk of the car.

85.title: Golf
85.author: Dik Browne
85.appears_in: reprinted on p. 153 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Hi returns a severely twisted golf club to Thirsty.

86.title: Golf
86.author: by Galbraith ; Gill Fox.
86.series: Aug. 25, 1967) "Nonsense! A Round of Golf Will Do You Good! I'll Sit Right Here and Wait While You Zip Through the Housework!"
notes: Summary: A husband addresses a wife surrounded by active children, dirty dishes and spills.

87.title: Golf
87.author: Art.
87.series: Oct. 3, 1967) "If You Don't Enjoy It, Why Do You Play It?"*
notes: Summary: Brutus shouts in anger with each shot.

88.title: Golf
88.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The guys are leaving for golf, which is no crazier than ice fishing; they're dressed for the weather and they'll use a red ball to see it in the snow.

89.title: Golf
89.author: Neg Cochran.
89.series: July 25, 1968) "That's What I Told Tom when he Called to Find out What Time He Should Meet You at the Golf Course in the Morning"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, not Born)
Summary: He's turning in early, saying he's going to get busy in the morning at the list of jobs she wants done.

90.title: Golf
90.author: by George Clark.
90.series: Jan. 20, 1969) "I've Chosen You to Go South With Me. I Need Someone to Drive My Golf Cart"*
notes: Summary: The boss bestows an honor.

91.title: Golf
91.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Though they run the risk of being accused of stalling, the painting crew has smuggled a television set into the room to watch golf.

92.title: Golf
92.author: Dik Browne
92.appears_in: reprinted on p. 152 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Thirsty has found his ball in the woods, and Hi offers to toss him what he needs from his golf bag.

93.title: Golf
93.author: [No author]
93.series: May 14, 1970) "He Might At Least Have Started the Mower For Her Before He Left"*
notes: Summary: Fred's master leaves for golf, and his mistress is displeased.

94.title: Golf
94.author: Roy Fox.
94.series: June 23, 1970) "Try to Squeeze in a Round of Golf Between your Business Appointments"
notes: Summary: The businessman takes the doctor's advice and is shown rushing through his golf game.

95.title: Golf
95.author: Pete Hansen.
95.series: July 27, 1970) "He'll Probably Be Disappointed Not to Make the Money"*
notes: Summary: The boss asks Lolly to cancel his golf lesson; out at the country club the pro jumps in the air and clicks his heels together.

96.title: Golf
96.author: Graham.
96.series: Oct. 9, 1970) "Play Some Golf, Relax, That's What His Doctor Said"*

97.title: Golf
97.author: by Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Mother gets the change from the groceries plus other things from the pocket: golf tee, paper clip, button, rubber bands and lint.

98.title: Golf
98.author: Mel Keefer, Jordan Lansky.
98.series: Jan. 22, 1971) "Why is it so Important for you to Play Golf and Play It Well?"*

99.title: Golf
99.author: Coker-Penn.
99.series: Mar. 1, 1971) "Okay, Mrs. Smart! Give Back My Golf Balls!"*
notes: Summary: She plays through the living room with the vacuum cleaner.

100.title: Golf
100.author: Pete Hansen.
100.series: Mar. 9, 1971) "I Wish I Were On the Moon"*
notes: Summary: His golf ball doesn't go as far as he'd like.

101.title: Golf
101.author: [No author]
101.series: May 14, 1971) "Why Is It We Always Seem To Have Laurel and Hardy Ahead of Us and Palmer and Nicklaus Behind Us?"*
notes: Summary: Hi and Thirsty are on a busy golf course.

102.title: Golf
102.author: Bill Yates
102.series: Feb. 3, 1972) "Some Men Can't Stand for a Woman to Beat Them at Golf"*
102.appears_in: p. 186 in The National Cartoonists Society Album 1972-77 ed.

103.title: Golf
103.author: by Gill Fox.
103.series: Mar. 13, 1972) "Oh, Come On, Marjorie! What's Wrong with a Little Cheating Between Friends?"
notes: Setting: Two women are playing golf.

104.title: Golf
104.author: Penn.
104.series: Apr. 22, 1972) "I Guess Now She Knows Who's Boss!"*
notes: Summary: Woody put his foot down and walked out on the chores his wife wanted him to do. He doesn't seem to know he's wearing an apron on the golf course.

105.title: Golf
105.author: by Gill Fox.
105.series: Apr. 22, 1972) "You Learn a Lot Playing with Myrna. She Went Around in 116 Strokes, Three Rumors and One Scandal!"
notes: Setting: Two women are talking in the country club dining room.

106.title: Golf
106.author: Penn.
106.series: Apr. 24, 1972) "Can You Think of Any Better Place to Hide My Golf Clubs?"*
notes: Summary: Woody takes out the garbage and sneaks out for golf at the same time. - Call no.: PN6726 f.B55 "golf clubs"

107.title: Golf
107.author: Parker & Hart
107.series: Apr. 28, 1972) "When they Finish, They'll be Six Miles from the Clubhouse"*
107.appears_in: reproduced on p. 153 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The king is building a new golf course for the ladies.

108.title: Golf
108.author: Art Sansom.
108.series: May 3, 1972) "That I Know How To Do!"*
notes: Summary: Brutus is not pleased when the golf instructor tells him to swing a few times without hitting the ball.

109.title: Golf
109.author: by Gill Fox.
109.series: May 6, 1972) "Good Heavens, Caroline! While I Was Waiting For You To Shoot, I Could Have Baked a Cake!"
notes: Setting: Two women are playing golf.

110.title: Golf
110.author: by Ham Fisher
110.appears_in: reproduced on p. 100-101 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Humphrey Pennyworth hits a bucket of balls, all at once.

111.title: Golf
111.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Elwood gets put on the late shift, and since he's a golf nut he likes it.

112.title: Golf
112.author: [No author]
112.series: Aug. 5, 1972) "You've Got To Watch Some of His Golfing Friends"*
notes: Summary: A golfer reports his score a little too optimistically.

113.title: Golf
113.author: Dik Browne
113.series: Feb. 23, 1973) "How Come the Years go by so Fast, and February Takes Forever?"*
113.appears_in: reprinted on p. 166 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Lois and Hi talk about how time flies, but Hi is standing with his golf clubs looking out at the snow.

114.title: Golf
114.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
114.series: Apr. 25, 1973) "They Claim that this Golf Game is Seventy-Five Percent Mental!"*
notes: Summary: Ken is talking about marriage to June, and says he's going to get in shape for the tournament; meanwhile Rex is upset and cancels his appointments.

115.title: Golf
115.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
115.series: May 2, 1973) "I'll Go to the Airport with You, June!"*
notes: Summary: June tells Ken he should go practice his golf instead, so they kiss goodbye at the hotel.

116.title: Golf
116.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
116.series: May 3, 1973) "What About His Illness, the Multiple Sclerosis?"*
notes: Summary: Rafe says he think Ken's going to make it back to the tour, and Rex says he's going to discharge Melissa.

117.title: Golf
117.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
117.series: May 4, 1973) "I Feel Good at the Ball!"*
notes: Summary: Ken looks good on the course, even though he's been away from the game.

118.title: Golf
118.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
118.series: May 7, 1973) "You've Got a Great Round Going, Ken! If you Par in, You'll have a Sixty-Five, a Course Record!"*
notes: Summary: June makes a lunch date with Brice Adam, while Ken's on the golf course.

119.title: Golf
119.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
notes: Summary: Ken tells Rafe he wants to pick up the tour in ten days, and that he's going to win the Open.

120.title: Golf
120.author: by Pete Hansen
120.appears_in: reproduced on p. 138 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Liz hits a drive so well that her male golfing partner's hat flies up and eyes pop out.

121.title: Golf
121.author: by Dal Curtis ; Bradley and Edgington.
notes: Summary: Rex congratulates Ken on a fine round of golf, and Ken wants to know what the doctor can tell him about his remission from M.S.

122.title: Golf
122.author: by Heimdahl & Stoffel.
122.series: July 19, 1973) "This is my Afternoon for Golf. I'll Have to See You in the Morning"*
notes: Summary: Cicero is playing doctor.

123.title: Golf
123.author: by Ted Key
123.appears_in: reproduced on p. 111 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: The young golfer is in wading pool with Hazel, getting ready to swing.

124.title: Golf
124.author: Dik Browne
124.series: Aug. 15, 1973) "I'm Going to Get Good at This Game if it Takes All Day!"*
124.appears_in: reprinted on p. 149 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Ditto practices golf with determination.

125.title: Golf
125.author: Mel Keefer.
125.series: Sept. 4, 1973) "I Don't Feel Like a Sad Trip!"*
notes: Summary: The U.S. team trails the British in the Ryder Cup, and though he's not Knute Rockne or Vince Lombardi, the coach would rather they travel home as winners.

126.title: Golf
126.author: Graham.
126.series: Sept. 14, 1973) "He Was In The Mixed Lounge Playing Bridge at the Time"*
notes: Summary: Fred's master sliced his drive on the eighteenth and hit General Arbuthnot.

127.title: Golf
127.author: Dik Browne
127.series: Sept. 22, 1973) "Somehow He Manages to Hiccup in the Middle of Every Backswing"*
127.appears_in: reprinted on p. 153 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Thirsty's timing is off, but Ditto's isn't.

128.title: Golf
128.author: Russell Myers.
128.series: Nov. 6, 1973) "If I Were You, I'd Cut Down on Calcium"
notes: Summary: A golf ball hits Irwin on the head while he's standing under a bird in a nest.

129.title: Golf
129.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The doctor slices the ball, and gets out his surgical equipment to sew it back together.

130.title: Golf
130.author: Pete Hansen.
130.series: Dec. 8, 1973) "The Boss Has Invited Me to Play Golf With Him. I Better Practice"*
notes: Summary: He's hitting a bucket of balls trying to shorten his drives.

131.title: Golf
131.author: [No author]
131.series: July/Aug. 1974) "The Monster in Hole 18" 10 p. in Strange Sports Stories, no. 6
notes: Data from Gene Reed.

132.title: Golf
132.author: Wayne Stayskal
132.series: 1975) "Don't Tell Me, That was a Slice, Right?"*
132.appears_in: reproduced on p. 119 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: A woman golfer has beheaded her instructor.

133.title: Golf
133.author: by WAP
133.series: Aug. 8, 1975) "What's That You Say, Scout- a 'People Leg' to the Right?"
133.appears_in: reproduced on p. 115 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Situation: Something of Scout the dog's perspective on golf.

134.title: Golf
134.author: [No author]
notes: Golf story.

135.title: Golf
135.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Wilma says it's either golf or his family, and Fred chooses golf.

136.title: Golf
136.author: Dik Browne
136.appears_in: reprinted on p. 153 of The Best of Hi and Lois (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986).
notes: Summary: Hi tells Thirsty that one drink relaxes him before a game of golf. Thirsty falls asleep while lining up his putt.

137.title: Golf
137.author: [No author]
notes: ca. 150 p. : chiefly ill. ; 20 cm.

138.appears_in: reproduced on p. 118 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Jughead's taking his golf shoes to be repaired, and Archie says they don't look like golf shoes.

139.title: Golf
139.author: Dik Browne
139.series: 1978) "Golf Balls, Tees and a Six Pack"*
139.appears_in: reproduced on p. 154 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Thirsty shows off his new golf bag, with an extra large pocket.

140.title: Golf
140.author: MacNelly
140.appears_in: reproduced on p. 121 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Cosmo is caddying for Shoe, and recommends an iron for a par 8 hole.

141.title: Golf
141.author: by George Gately

141.appears_in: reproduced on p. 136 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Heathcliff is in the locker room after a round of golf.

142.title: Golf
142.author: by Mort Walker
142.series: Aug. 24, 1978) "So Enough about My Day. What's All This about You Shooting a Hole In One?"*
142.appears_in: reproduced on p. 169 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Situation: General Halftrack is in bed with his wife, his golf clothes and his golf equipment.

143.title: Golf
